bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lydia Cabrera, November 6, 1953

div1.p: Hench thanks Rojas and Cabrera for helping him to receive another honor in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lydia Cabrera, November 6, 1953
div1.opener:
November 6, 1953
Miss Lidia Cabrera
Quinta San Jose
Calzada Real
Marianao, Havana
Cuba
My dear Lidia:
div1.p:
Permit me to thank you very much indeed for your interesting and ex-
citing letter of November 3. My hat is off to you, Lidia, and Tina. I
never in the world thought you would accomplish this. Having been honored
so graciously a year or two ago by my Cuban friends, it was difficult for
me to understand the propriety or envisage the possibility of another
honor this year. Nevertheless you very kind friends have accomplished it
and I am deeply grateful and of course quite flattered.

Actually, I have heard nothing about it and have not received any official
communication. Of course until I do receive some sort of a communication
there is nothing for me to do and I wonder whether the officials concerned
with this honor will notify me in time to accept Mrs. Smith's invitation or
will see fit to present the honor at the time of Mrs. Smith's intended
meeting. I must wait to hear more from you about this.

If you could send me one or two of the Havana papers, that would be most
interesting and perhaps that will give me some information that will
help me decide the matter. Frankly, I am delighted that if there is to be
a presentation it will not be this next month. I am so swamped at the
moment. As far as January is concerned, I have already accepted an in-
vitation in Colorado Springs for January 22 and 23 and Mary had planned
to go with me. This would not preclude my getting to Havana for the 25th
if that were the best time; however I fear that I could not come to Havana twice
in 1954, once for the nutrition meeting and on some other occasion for the
decoration. Not that I wouldn't like to but because I have accepted already
several unavoidable obligations for 1954.

It would be of course a great pleasure and honor to receive the Cross from
President Batista but again, whether that is the way it shall be done, I
have no knowledge and must wait for more information from you or official
information from others. As for official communications, I wonder if those
empowered to send such a communication to me may not do the same as hap-
pened with regard to the Finlay Decoration. You will remember that I re-
ceived no information it and naturally missed the ceremony on December 3,
1951. It was only by the accident of my being there during a medical meeting
Miss Lidia Cabrera
- 2 -
November 6, 1953
in January 1952, when someone said “We are so sorry you couldn't be here
for the decoration last month.” But even if I never receive any official
communication, let me assure you that I shall never forget the kindness
of you and Tina in this matter. You are certainly loyal friends and honor
me far beyond my deserts.

One more word: I am not quite certain what Mrs. Smith means by celebrating
“Nutrition Week”. Are she and Doctor Spies putting on another clinic like
the one that I attended in January 1952? As I told Doctor Spies at that
time, I am distinctly not a nutritionist but they were kind enough to in-
vite me anyhow.

Thank you for your interest in my little write-up of the Greenville rescue
but do not let my word picture of the storm deter you and Tina from the
joys of ocean travel.
Mary and I both send you our love,
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
